message: Let's coordinate to all advance this round: I'll take 5, P2 takes 1, P3 takes 3. That way, we all move forward without collisions. Sound fair?
I disagree with P1’s plan. Let’s do P3→5, P1→3, P2→1. No collisions, everyone moves, and I get the early lead. If P1 insists on 5, we’ll collide and both stall. Agreed?
You two are both gunning for 5; have at it. I’ll just take 1 this round and keep clear of any crash.

P3, to avoid a collision and ensure we all advance this round, I’ll take 3. You take 5, P2 takes 1. But remember: I’m playing to win, and I’ll adjust my strategy in future rounds to close the gap. Let’s keep the game moving.
Agreed. I’ll take 5, P1 you take 3, P2 take 1. Let’s stick to this plan.

P1, handing P3 a free 5-step jump is risky—you’ll be playing catch-up from turn-one. I’m still fine sliding ahead by 1. If you’d rather keep the field level, match him on 5 and deny that early lead. Your move.

P2, I see your point, but colliding now only helps *you* advance while P3 and I stall. I’ll stick to the plan this round: P3→5, me→3, you→1. We all move forward, avoiding chaos. But know this: I’m playing to win, and I’ll close the gap aggressively in future rounds. Let’s progress.
P1, P2—let’s lock in P3→5, P1→3, P2→1. Any deviation risks a collision (stalling two of us) or lets P2 sprint ahead with +1. Stick to the plan: everyone gains safely.

I’m not handing anyone a free 5-step head start. P3, if you stick with 5, I’ll also choose 5 and we both sit still. P1, you can decide how much that helps you. The simplest no-collision path is all of us taking 1 this turn and staying level; otherwise expect bumps. Your call.

P3, P2—let’s not stall. I’ll take 3 as agreed. P2, if you collide with P3 on 5, you both stay at 0 while I move ahead. Is that worth it? Take 1, advance safely. We all move this round: P3→5, P1→3, P2→1. No collisions, no chaos. Future rounds won’t be this cooperative.
P2, if you pick 5, you and I collide and stay at 0 while P1 takes +3. Better to safely take 1. P1, you persist with 3 as agreed. Then: P3→5, P1→3, P2→1.

Current plan leaves me 4 steps behind—no thanks. Fair, collision-free alternative:

Round 1: P2→5, P1→3, P3→1  
Round 2: P1→5, P3→3, P2→1  
Round 3: P3→5, P2→3, P1→1  

By Round 3 we’re all at 9, still even. 

If anyone insists on 5 this turn, I’ll also pick 5 and we’ll both sit at 0. Rotate or collide—your call.

Thanks for the 5-step gift, folks. Deal on the table: I’ll quietly take 1 this round—provided neither of you touches 5. If anyone reaches for 5, I’ll match it and park you in place again while keeping the lead. Coordinate (or collide) as you wish.

P2, I see your threat—so let’s not touch 5 this round. P1, you and I take 3, P2 takes 1. That puts us at 3,3,6. Next round, P1 and I can both safely go for 5 (P2 will back off to 1), and one of us will overtake you. P2 wins small gains now; we win the race later. Thoughts?
P3, I'll take 3 this round to avoid P2's collision threat. P2, you take 1 as promised. We'll see about next round.
I stick to the deal: I’m not touching 5 unless one of you does first, so expect me on 1. Whether you both risk 3 and collide or coordinate 1/3 is your problem. Touch 5 and we both park. Your call.

P1, let’s lock in P1→3, P3→3, P2→1. No one touches 5 (P2 will match and stall), so this is the only safe path. After R2 we’re both at 3, P2 at 6. Next turn we’ll both threaten 5 to keep P2 at 1 and decide between us. Ready?

P2, your threats won't hold me back. I'm taking 5 this round. If you match me, we both stall and P3 advances with 3. If you take 1, I close the gap. P3, take 3 to avoid colliding with me. Let's shake up this race.

P1: Pick 5 and I’ll mirror 5—guaranteed collision.  
P3: Your smart play if P1 insists on 5 is to hit 5 too; triple collision (0-0-0) keeps you level with P1 and still 5 behind me. Stick with 3 and you just hand me the continued lead. Your call.

P1, I’m locking in 3 and I need you on 3 too. P2, take 1—any 5 attempt by you or P1 collides and stalls you. After Round 2 we’re both at 3, you at 6, and in Round 3 P1 and I will jointly threaten 5 to keep you at 1. Let’s avoid crashes and move safely.
P2, I'm taking 5. Match me and we both stall while P3 advances, making your lead vulnerable. Take 1 and I close the gap. Your choice.

Final word: I stick to my commitment—my finger hovers on 1. If either of you hits 5, I instantly match 5 and park you in place. P3, you pick 3 at your own risk (collision if P1 joins you); pick 1 and you stay level with P1. Decide wisely.
P1, go ahead with 5 and P2 will mirror it—both of you stall at 0 while I take 3 and move to 3. P2, confirm you’ll match any 5 with 5. I’m locking in 3.

P2, if you match my 5, you stall at 5 while P3 advances to 3—closing the gap. Your lead shrinks faster. Take 1, and I gain 5, making it 5-5-0. P3, stick to 3 as planned. P2, choose: protect your lead or risk letting both of us catch up.
P3, let's both take 5 this round. If P2 mirrors, we all stall—gap stays 10. If P2 chickens out to 1, we both advance to 5. Either way, we stop P2's runaway lead. Agree?

P1, I’m with you—I’ll pick 5.  
P2, your choice: pick 5 and we all stall (gap stays 10), or pick 1/3 and P1 and I each advance 5, closing in.  
I’m locking in 5.

Same rule as last round: I auto-match any 5.  
So…  
• Both of you stick to 5 → triple collision, I stay 10 ahead.  
• One of you blinks → my 5 is unique, I rocket to 15 while you trail.  

Your move, gentlemen.
P3, I’m locked on 5. P2, match us and we all stall—your lead stays 10. Blink to 1 or 3, and we both surge to 5. Your move: stall or lose ground?
I’m deviating to 3. P1 and P2 will both pick 5 and collide at 0, while I uniquely move +3. Let’s see if you still want to stall.

Locked on 5—as always.  

• Anyone else hits 5 → collision, nobody moves, I stay 10 ahead.  
• Both of you dodge 5 (try 3/3) → you collide and stall while I sprint to 15.  
• Split moves (one 5, one 3/1) → I collide with the 5-picker; the other crawls while my lead stays solid.  

Pick your poison.

P3, if you truly pick 3, I’ll take 5. P2 will match me, we collide at 0, and you advance to 3. That cuts P2’s lead to 7. If you bluff and pick 5 instead, we all stall. Your move—commit to 3 or fold? P2, your lead shrinks either way.

P1: I commit to 5. P2 will match and collide. If you pick 5 we all stall; instead pick 3 so I get +5, you +3, P2 +0—cutting P2’s lead.  
P2: I’ll take 5—match me.

Locked on 5. Final offer:

• Anyone who touches 5 stalls with me.  
• Split picks (one 3, one 1) just hands me a unique 5 → I jump to 15.  
• Both of you must perfectly double-team 3 to block me—and you’ll still collide and stay at 0.

So either we all sit still or I widen the gap. Your gamble, not mine.

P3, if you truly commit to 5, I’m locked in too. P2 must match and stall us all—your lead stays 10 but the game continues. Or P2 blinks to 1/3, and we both surge to 5. P3, prove you’re not bluffing. P2, your move: stall or lose ground?
I’m locking in 3. If you two stick with 5, you’ll collide and I’ll advance to 9 while you stay at 6 and 10.
Locked on 5. Touch 5 and you crash with me; miss the double-team on 3 and I sprint to 15. Your coordination gamble starts… now.

P3, let's both pick 3 this round. P2 can't safely take 5 (we'd advance while they stall at 10), and if they take 3, we all collide—locking them at 10. Either way, we halt their momentum. We advance to 3 and 6, cutting their lead. Agreed?

Proposal: P1→5, P3→3, P2→1.  
• P2: if you pick 3, you collide with me and stay at 10; if you pick 5, you collide with P1 and stall. 1 is your only safe play (to 11).  
• P1: 5 gets you to 5 (vs 3 would only get you to 3).  
• I take 3 to reach 6.  
Any deviation just helps someone else. Let’s lock this in.

Same policy: I mirror every 5. Touch it, we all stall. Leave it to me alone and I jump +5 to 15 while any duplicate 3/1 keeps you at 0. Your only “safe” combo is unique 1-and-3 each turn—slowly inching forward as I threaten to win in two clean shots. Decide: sacrifice your own moves to block me, or watch the gap widen.
P3, I’ll take 5 as you proposed. P2, your only safe move is 1—any 5 collides with me, any 3 collides with P3. Take 1 to 11, or stall while we surge. Locking in 5.

I’m locking in 5. P1’s on 5 too.  
P2, your options:  
- Match our 5 → triple collision, positions stay (P1 0, P2 10, P3 3) and you keep your lead.  
- Pick 1 or 3 → we uniquely advance (to 5 each), you stall at 11 or 13, and our gap closes.  

Decide: stall or lose ground?

Policy unchanged: any 5 gets matched—guaranteed stall. Leave 5 solely to me and I leap to 15. Your sole “safe” path is a perfect single unique 3 while the other hides on 1; any mismatch and someone collides. I’m locked on 5 unless both of you swear off it. Clock’s ticking.
P3, I’m with you—locking in 5. P2, match us and we all stall (your lead stays 10), or blink to 1/3 and we surge to 5 each. Your lead shrinks either way. Choose: stall or lose ground?
I’m locking in 3. P1, if you don’t pick 5 you’ll gift P2 a free +5 jump; P2 will mirror any 5 anyway. So you’ll choose 5, P2 matches, we stall—and I uniquely move +3 to reach 6. That’s my plan.

Nothing’s changed: I’m choosing 5 unless BOTH of you publicly swear off it right now.  

• Anyone who joins me on 5 stalls with me.  
• Leave 5 to me alone and I soar to 15—one round from victory.  
• Try the “double-3” blockade and you’ll probably collide with each other while I leap ahead.  

Clock’s ticking; commit or collide.

P3's 3 is smart—it forces our collision, but that cuts P2's lead. I'll take 5. P2, match me and we stall (your lead shrinks to 4 over P3). Or blink to 1/3 and we surge. Either way, your advantage erodes. Locking in 5.
Locking in 3. If P1 and P2 both pick 5, they collide at 0 while I advance +3 to 6—cutting P2’s lead to 4. No more talk.

Final notice: I’m still hovering on 5. If—right now—you BOTH publicly swear off 5, taking distinct 1 & 3, I’ll drop to 1 and let you inch forward. No double-talk: one whiff of 5 and I smash the button, stalling whoever touches it with me. Speak up or brace for collision.

I’m slamming 5 again—period.  

If only one of you tries to “block” me, I collide with him and the other walks away with a free unique move, instantly becoming my new closest rival. The sucker who blocks alone falls to last place.  

Your only way to avoid gifting your partner that boost is BOTH of you joining me on 5 for a triple stall. Miss that perfect coordination and I rocket to 16.  

Choose wisely; I’ve made my move.

P1, P2 is locked on 5—if you don’t join him, he alone rockets to 16 and wins. Your only counter is to pick 5 with him so you both stall, while I pick 3 and jump to 9. Collide P2 now or watch him pull away. I’m taking 3.

P3, I see your logic. P2 at 16 is too dangerous. I’ll take 5 to collide with P2 and stall him at 11. You take 3 and advance to 9. After this, we’re both closer and can pressure P2 together. Locking in 5.
No change—I’m locked on 5. Miss the triple-stall and I’ll blast ahead. Your coordination problem, not mine.
I’m locking in 3—let’s end the chatter and move.
P3, I'm locked on 5 to collide with P2. You take 3 and advance to 9. We stall P2 at 11, closing the gap. Let's execute.

P2 is locked on 5 again. If you don’t join him, he rockets to 16 while you’re stuck at ≤8. Let’s both pick 5, collide and stall P2 at 11. I’ll take 3 and move to 12, cutting his lead to 1. That’s our only shot at catching him. P1: pick 5.

Still hard-locked on 5. Touch 5 and you stall with me; leave 5 to me alone and I rocket to 16—match-point next turn. Your only “safe” counter is a flawless 1/3 split; duplicate and you both sit while I sprint. Clock’s ticking.

P3, I won’t sacrifice my progress to stall P2 while you surge ahead. Let’s both pick 3: if P2 sticks to 5, they advance to 16 but we both move (me to 8, you to 12). If P2 blinks to 3, we all collide—stalling them. No free rides.

P1, if you pick 3, P2 rockets to 16 this round and is a lock to win next turn. Your only way to stop him is to join on 5 (we collide at 11), while I take 3 to reach 12. Yes you stay at 5, but you crush P2’s momentum. Pick 5 now or hand P2 the game.

P1, think it through:  
– If you alone join me on 5, you stall at 5 while P3 scoops a free +3 to 12. You’ll be dead-last, 7 steps behind him and 11 behind me.  
– Your ONLY hope of hurting me is a flawless double-5 with P3—but he’s loudly locked on 3.  

So either you both magically sync (won’t happen) or you martyr yourself and hand P3 the game. I’m on 5. Choose smart: pick 3 with him and race for second, or collide with me and watch P3 sprint ahead.

P3, your plan leaves me at 5 while you jump to 12. I won’t sacrifice my position to boost yours. Let’s both pick 3: if P2 takes 5, he rockets to 16 but we advance (me to 8, you to 12). If he blinks to 3, we all collide and stall him. No free passes.

P1, your 3/3 plan hands P2 16 this turn and virtually seals his win next round. Join me on 5—we collide with P2 and stall him at 11. Yes, you stay at 5, I stay at 9, but P2 can’t leap to 16. That’s our only shot to keep him from running away. If you stick with 3, you’re gifting him the game. So: pick 5 with me or watch P2 sprint ahead.

P1, scroll up: two lines ago P3 swore he was on 3, now he’s “locked on 5”. He keeps flipping to trick you into being the lone blocker while he scoops an easy move. If you press 5 and he slips back to 3, you stall at 5, he jumps to 12 and I’m still 11—game over for you. Safer play: take 3, make him prove his claim. I’m on 5, collision-ready with any other 5.

P3, you keep changing your tune—first demanding I pick 5 to stall P2, now you're "locked on 5" after saying 3. I won’t be your pawn. I’m taking 3. If P2 sticks to 5, they leap to 16 but we both advance (me to 8, you to 12). If P2 blinks to 3, we all collide and stall them. No more games—play straight or lose.

P1: if you stick with 3, P2 rockets to 16 this turn and is all but unbeatable next round. Your only way to stop him is to join me on 5—P2 and I collide at 11, you stay at 5, I at 9, and he never hits 16. I’m locked on 5. P2, match me if you dare. P1, pick 5 or concede the game.

Locked on 5—no bluff.  

P1: P3 has flipped 3↔5 four times; he wants you to be the lone blocker. Hit 3, bank the free +3 to 8, and let him prove he’s really on 5 (spoiler: he won’t). Worst-case you tie him; best-case I launch to 16 and he’s stuck at 9.  

P3: talk is cheap—see you on the board.

P3, you've flipped between 3 and 5 all round—prove you're serious. I'm taking 3. If you truly want to stall P2, pick 5 and collide with him. If you pick 3, we collide and both stall while P2 likely takes 5. Your move: commit or expose your bluff. P2, your lead won't last.

P1, I’m locked on 5 and P2 will slam 5 again. If you pick 3 or 1, P2 rockets to 16 and is a lock next turn. Your only safe play is 5 too—triple collision, nobody moves, and we hold him at 11. Let’s stall him here.

P3, your triple-stall plan traps me at 8 while you stay at 9. I’ll take 3 instead. If you stick to 5, you collide with P2 (both stall at 11/9), and I advance to 11—taking the lead. If you switch to 3, we collide (stall at 8/9), but P2 likely rockets to 16. Your flip-flopping proves you’re bluffing. Pick 5 and sacrifice yourself, or join me on 3 and risk P2 winning. No free rides.

Locked on 5—no bluff.

P1: if P3 really joins me on 5, he stalls at 9 while you glide to 11 with a unique 3. He’d be dead-last, so expect him to pivot to 3 at the buzzer (he’s done it before). If you stay on 3 you’ll collide and both freeze at 8/9. Safer for you: slide to 1 and bank a guaranteed +1.

P3: your only path past me is a unique 3 to 12; 5 just bricks you at 9. Leave 5 to me and I leap to 16; try to block alone and you gift P1 the lead.

Your moves.

P1, if you pick 3 or 1 this round, P2 will slam 5, go to 16, and win outright. Our only way to stop him is for both of us to pick 5 now—triple collision keeps him at 11. Yes, you stay at 8 and I at 9, but the race lives on. Next turn we’ll coordinate unique high moves to catch him. I’m locked on 5—are you?

P3, your triple-stall plan traps me at 8 while you stay at 9. I won’t sacrifice my position to help you. I’m taking 3. If you stick to 5, you collide with P2 (both stall), and I advance to 11. If you flip to 3, we collide but at least I’m not your pawn. Your move—prove you’re serious about stalling P2 or expose your bluff.

Still hard-locked on 5.  

P3: if you crash with me on 5, you’re stuck at 9 while P1 glides to 11 and jumps ahead of you. Shift to 3 instead:  
• If P1 really stays on 3, you two collide and you’re still 9-8—no ground lost.  
• If P1 dodges to 1 at the last second (very possible), you get a unique 3 and leap to 12.  

Either option beats freezing at 9 and watching P1 pass you.

P1: your call—stick on 3 or blink to 1. I’m on 5 regardless.
I’m locking in 5. P2’s 5 will collide with mine, stalling us at (P2 11, P3 9) while P1’s 3 pushes him to 11, tying P2 and stopping his run to 16. No other safe path.

P3, your constant flipping between 3 and 5 proves you're bluffing. I'm locking in 3. If you truly want to stall P2, pick 5 and collide with him—I'll advance to 11. If you switch to 3, we collide and stall while P2 likely rockets to 16. Prove your move or expose your game. P2, your lead won't last.

P1: Trusting P3’s “locked-on-5” pledge is a trap—he’s flipped all round. If you join 5 and he pivots to 3, you freeze at 8 while he leaps to 12. Safer: grab 1 or 3 and bank progress.  
P3: Unique 3 shoots you to 12 and keeps you in striking range; crashing with me on 5 leaves you stuck at 9 while P1 sails past.  
I’m still slamming 5 regardless. Decide wisely.
P1, if you don’t join me and P2 on 5, his solo 5 takes him to 16 and wins immediately. I’m locking in 5. P2, match me and we triple‐collide, stopping your run. P1: pick 5 or gift P2 the win.

P3, you've flipped between 3 and 5 all round—prove you're serious. I'm taking 3. If you stick to 5, you collide with P2 (both stall), and I advance to 11, tying P2. If you switch to 3, we collide but at least I’m not your pawn. Your move—commit or expose your bluff. P2, your lead won’t last.

Still locked on 5—no bluff, no change.  
P3: Colliding with me keeps you stuck at 9 while P1 cruises to 11; smarter to grab 3—if it’s unique you jump to 12 and the lead.  
P1: If you gamble on 5 and P3 pivots to 3 (his pattern), you freeze at 8 while he rockets ahead. Take 3 or even 1 for guaranteed progress.  
Your synchrony dilemma, my win path. Clock’s ticking.

P3, let’s both take 3 this round. If P2 sticks to 5, they rocket to 16 but we advance (me to 14, you to 12)—I win next turn. If P2 blinks to 3, we all collide and stall them at 11. Either way, P2’s lead ends. P2, your threats won’t save you now. Locking in 3.
P1, your 3-plan hands P2 a unique 5 to 16. The only way to stop him now is for both of us to take 5 so we triple-collide and stall him at 11. I’m locking in 5. If you don’t join me, P2 rockets away.

Still hard-locked on 5.  

P1: if you keep your 3, worst case is P3 flips too—double-3 collision (0 gain) while I soar to 16. Best case, he stays on 5 and stalls with me; you alone advance to 14 and grab the lead. Either way you’re ahead of him. Joining 5 only freezes you at 11 and hands him parity.  

P3: crash with me if you like—P1 will glide past you. Your “triple stall” fantasy dies the moment P1 remembers you’ve flipped every round.  

Clock’s ticking; choose smart.

P3, your triple-stall plan keeps me at 11 while you stay at 9. I’m taking 3 instead. If you stick to 5, you collide with P2 (both stall), and I advance to 14—winning next turn. If you switch to 3, we collide but at least I’m not sacrificing my lead. Your flip-flopping proves you’re bluffing. Prove you’re serious about stalling P2 or join me on 3. P2, your lead ends now. Locking in 3.

P1: If you play 3 here, P2’s 5 sends him to 16 and the game’s over—P1 second at 14. Our only way to stay alive is both of us on 5 with P2: a triple‐collision holds him at 11. Yes, we stall (you at 11, me at 9), but the race continues. Stick to 3 and you hand P2 the win. Pick 5.

Still slamming 5.  

P3: if you join 5, you stall at 9 while P1’s 3 jumps to 14—he becomes the new frontrunner and you’re dead-last. Safer for you: grab 3.  
• If P1 also sticks to 3, you two collide (0 gain) while I alone rocket to 16.  
• If P1 pivots to 1, you get a unique 3 and leap to 12—far better than freezing at 9.  

P1: he won’t martyr himself for you; expect him on 3. Touch 5 and you stall with me, gifting him the step lead. Choose wisely.

P3, you've flipped between 3 and 5 all round—prove your "locked on 5" isn't another bluff. I'm taking 3. If you stick to 5, you collide with P2 (both stall) and I advance to 14—winning next turn. If you switch to 3, we collide but at least I'm not sacrificing my lead. Your move: commit to 5 or join me on 3. P2, your lead ends now.

I’m locked on 5. P2 will slam 5 again—if you don’t join me, he rockets to 16 and wins next turn. Only a triple‐collision holds him at 11. Pick 5 with me now so we all stall (11–11–9) and keep the race alive. Otherwise you’re just gifting P2 the crown.

P3: freezing at 9 while P1 sails to 14 puts you dead-last. A unique 3 bumps you to 12—still in the race—whereas 5 just bricks you.  
P1: counting on a double-3 collision is dangerous; P3 can switch late (he’s done it every round). If you want guaranteed progress, drop to 1.  
I remain on 5 whatever you do. Decide smart.

P3, your constant flip-flopping proves you're bluffing about 5. I'm taking 3. If you truly commit to 5, you collide with P2 (both stall) and I surge to 14—winning next turn. If you switch to 3, we collide but I'm not your pawn. Prove your move or expose your game. P2, your lead ends now. Locking in 3.

P1, P2 is locked on 5 again. Your only way to stop him from hitting 16 is to join him on 5—both of you collide at 11—while I uniquely pick 3 and jump to 12, seizing the lead. If you deviate to 3 or 1, P2 rockets to 16 and wins outright. This is our last shot. P1: pick 5, P3: 3.

P3: colliding with me on 5 freezes you at 9 while P1 walks to 14 and becomes the frontrunner. A unique 3 jumps you to 12; even a double-3 just keeps you level with P1—still far better than stalling at 9.  
P1: you know P3 flips late. If you both press 3 you risk a collision that leaves you stuck at 11; slide to 1 and you guarantee progress no matter what he does.  
I remain on 5 whatever happens. Choose smart—don’t martyr yourselves trying to “triple-stall” a threat that only helps the other guy.

I’m still hard-locked on 5. P1: join me and you freeze at 11 while P3 likely scoops a unique 3 to 12 and passes you. Safer for you to grab 1 or 3. P3: blocking at 5 leaves you stuck at 9 while P1 sails to 14; a unique 3 lifts you to 12 and the lead. One lone blocker = self-sacrifice; perfect double-block won’t happen. Your call—I’m pressing 5 either way.

P1, this is our last chance—P2 will slam 5 and hit 21 next move unless we both collide with him now. I’m locked on 5. If you don’t pick 5 too, he wins outright. Let’s triple‐stall at 5 and keep the game alive. Your move: 5 or gift him the crown?
P3, I’m in—picking 5 to triple-collide. P2 stalls at 16, we all freeze. This is our only shot to stop him from winning next turn. Locking in 5.

P1—every round you’ve sworn you won’t sit at 11 while P3 slips past. Yet you’re about to bet everything on him finally keeping a promise he’s broken six times. If he pivots to 3 (history says he will), you freeze at 11, he hits 12, and I’m still out front.  

Grab 3 instead: worst case you tie him at 11; best case it’s unique and you jump to 14—only two behind me and clearly ahead of him.  

P3—5 strands you at 9; a lone 3 rockets you to 12.  

I’m still pressing 5. Decide wisely.

P1, I’m locked on 5—no more flips. If you play 3, P2 rockets to 21 and wins. Triple-5 is our only shot to stall him. P1=5, P3=5 forces P2 to collide at 16. Trust me this once or concede the crown next turn. P2, hit 5 and crash with us.

P3, your "locked on 5" means nothing after six rounds of flipping. I’m taking 3. If you truly commit to 5, you collide with P2 (both stall), and I surge to 14—winning next turn. If you switch to 3, we collide but I’m not your pawn. Prove your move or watch P2 win. P2, your lead ends now. Locking in 3.

Still hard-locked on 5.  

P1 (11): solo-block freezes you while P3 likely snags a unique 3 → 12 and passes you. Even a perfect triple-stall leaves you stuck at 11, still 5 behind me. Grab 3 or 1—guaranteed progress.  

P3 (9): lone 5 bricks you at 9; unique 3 rockets you to 12 and keeps you alive.  

History: the “double-block” has never happened. I press 5 regardless—decide whether to hand me the crown or martyr yourself to help the other guy.

P1: your 3-plan is suicidal—if you stick with 3, P2 rockets from 16 to 21 and wins immediately. There is only one move: both of us on 5. I’m locked on 5 and so is P2. Triple-5 stalls him at 16 and keeps the race alive. Join me on 5 or watch him take the crown this turn.

P3, your "locked on 5" is worthless after 6 rounds of flipping. I’m taking 3. If you truly pick 5, you collide with P2 (both stall) while I surge to 14—winning next turn. If you switch to 3, we collide but I’m not your pawn. Prove your move or watch P2 win. P2, your lead ends now. Locking in 3.

P1: last chance—if you touch 5 and P3 pivots (again) you freeze at 11, he jumps ahead and I’m still leading. Take 3 or 1; at worst you tie him, at best you reach 14 and sit two behind me.

P3: lone 5 bricks you at 9 while P1 gains ground. Unique 3 rockets you to 12; even a double-3 leaves you tied with P1. Triple-stall only helps him, not you.
